Wagner Labor ArchiveElmer Holmes Bobst Library70 Washington Square South10th FloorNew York, NY 10012(212) 998-2630tamiment.wagner@nyu.eduThis finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace 2018-05-11T20:45:17Description is in EnglishDescribing Archives: A Content Standard
Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Harry Gannes Manuscript From the Cradle to the Factory TAM 296
0.25 Linear Feet in 1 manuscript box
circa 1930-1941 Harry Gannes (1901-1941), at one time served (during the Popular Front era, circa 1935 - 1939) as the foreign editor of the Daily Worker, the newspaper of the Communist Party, USA. The collection consists of "From the Cradle to the Factory," an unpublished typescript (circa 1930s), 43 pp., about child labor in the United States. 1
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Sam Darcy in 1985. The accession number associated with this gift is 1985.014.
Arrangement
This collection is arranged into one folder.
Historical/Biographical Note
Harry Gannes (1901-1941), at one time served (during the Popular Front era, circa 1935 - 1939) as the foreign editor of the Daily Worker, the newspaper of the Communist Party, USA.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; Harry Gannes Manuscript From the Cradle to the Factory; TAM 296; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Scope and Contents
The collection consists of "From the Cradle to the Factory," an unpublished typescript (circa 1930s), 43 pp., about child labor in the United States.
Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
Researchers must use photocopies.
Conditions Governing Use
Copyright (and related rights to publicity and privacy) to materials in this collection created by Harry Gannes was not transferred to New York University. Permission to use materials must be secured from the copyright holder.
Communists -- United States. Manuscripts for publication. Child labor |z United States. Darcy, Samuel, 1905-
